newsitem.title: USA: UN says report of Iraq oil monitor arrests untrue.
newsitem.headline: UN says report of Iraq oil monitor arrests untrue.

text.p: The United Nations said Friday that a report claiming some of its staff in northern Iraq had been arrested by a Kurdish group is untrue.
"We've checked with Baghdad and we deny it," said U.N. spokesman Hiro Ueki of Thursday's report.

BBC Monitoring quoted the Iraqi Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) radio Thursday saying six U.N. envoys monitoring the distribution of fuel in northern Iraq were arrested by in areas under the control of the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP).
Ueki said checks by the U.N.'s Security Coordinator and staff in Iraq turned up no evidence of any interference with U.N. personnel.

The PUK and the KDP are rival factions in Kurdish northern Iraq. The KDP, backed by Saddam Hussein's troops, wrested territory from the PUK last year, a move which led to a four-month delay in starting the U.N. "oil-for-food" deal which allows Iraq to sell up to $2 billion of oil over six months to buy badly needed food and other humanitarian goods.
